descendants.content:
Note the time scale Masters puts on the various disasters that may befall YOU: Less than 5 years to a 2008-style insurance / mortgage crisis, 15 years for sea level rise to burst the coastal real estate bubble, cracks developing in the global food supply system, and then there's "black swan" events that will catch us completely off guard, such as the Mississippi river changing its course.

And not enough of us are talking about this, so we're largely unprepared.

https://yaleclimateconnections.org/2024/08/when-will-climate-change-turn-life-in-the-u-s-upside-down/

card.title: When will climate change turn life in the U.S. upside down?
card.description: Intensifying extreme weather events and an insurance crisis are likely to cause significant economic and political disruption in the U.S. sometime in the next 15 years.

descendants.content:
"On a personal level, you should prepare for the intensifying #ClimateChange storm like you would for an approaching major hurricane. If you’re going to stay in place, know your risk, get more insurance, stock up on supplies, weatherproof your home, and get your finances in order.

And if you live in a sufficiently risky place, leave. "

https://yaleclimateconnections.org/2024/08/what-should-you-do-to-prepare-for-the-climate-change-storm/

card.title: What should you do to prepare for the climate change storm?
card.description: Do you stand your ground or seek out a climate haven? Some resources to help you decide.

descendants.content: @CelloMomOnCars “We need what’s been called ‘cathedral thinking.’ That is, the people who started working on that stone foundation, they never saw the thing finished. It took generations to get these major works done.”

descendants.content:
@CelloMomOnCars

I disfavor idea that technology is a solution to climate change. Climate change is not a technological problem, it is a social economic dynamic. We require of ourselves a Rube Goldberg exercise using a 2000 lb metal box to go fetch a carton of milk. This is not sophisticated when you think about it why don’t we put the store next to where we live when we put work right next to where we live then we would do the big 2000 pound metal box

descendants.content:
@GhostOnTheHalfShell

I think most of our problem is that the people who sell us the stuff we burn to make our metal box go are in the way of real and fast climate action.

There are plenty of Americans who want to bike, walk, or take the bus, but the infrastructure is missing.

(I have bad news for you: The average midsized SUV is now more like 4000-5000 lbs. Their footprint is not much smaller than that of WWII tanks. So yeah, using that to get a quart of milk is ludicrous).

descendants.content:
@CelloMomOnCars We’re saved when a town’s people demand changes. Cities are fixing zoning laws, but the financing to rework a neighborhood into mixed use is not quite in place. In Ca, adding a second unit to a single home lot raises issues of mortgage etc.

Cities could take over the role of extending financing. Trade businesses to cater to a mixed use world also must evolve.

descendants.content:
@GhostOnTheHalfShell

I'm just talking of striping in bike lanes.
For the cost of paint (okay, thermoplastic, but you know what I mean) you can encourage more people to ride their bike. And now with e-bikes you don't have to arrive sweaty.

But the people who shout "Save the parking!!

(They mean *car* parking. It would be nice when we arrive at the point that everyone has to specify *car" when they mean car parking). I can rant about this stuff all day.

descendants.content:
@GhostOnTheHalfShell

Even when a town's people demand changes, changes don't always come. I once went to a panel on bike advocacy. In town after town after town it was "We know that most of us want bike lanes but 2-5 merchants stop it."

It's about Car Brain.
It's about the power structure.
It's about the power structure having Car Brain.

(And yes, the Dutch had all those things. But their people fought for bike lanes, and won).

descendants.content:
@CelloMomOnCars @GhostOnTheHalfShell because I need a van that averages 20mpg* to haul my wheelchair, I was really glad to get a wheelchair that can go a lot more miles than my old one on one battery, because now I can seriously run errands in it, to the extent my suburban infrastructure allows it.

*There are now hybrid vans but there weren't when I got mine, I think it's wasteful to buy a whole new one right now, besides expensive, and the location of the batteries is really inconvenient for my wheelchair camping needs. I'm sure there will be something much better available when this van wears out.
